summary: This is an email chain from July 2020 between a US Attorney's Office (USANYS) contractor and another individual, discussing the identification and upload of specific data sets (identified by codes like NYCO24392) to a database (Relativity) for the case US v. Epstein. The conversation involves verifying the accuracy and existence of certain data drives.

persons.name: Contractor
persons.context: A contractor for the US Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USANYS) who is responsible for sending out data sets for upload to the Relativity database in the US v. Epstein case.

events.title: Data Sets Sent for Upload
events.description: The USANYS contractor sends a list of seven data set folders (e.g., NYCO24363, NYCO24392) for upload to the Relativity database for the US v. Epstein case.

events.title: Verification of Data Drive Numbers
events.description: Email correspondence questioning the accuracy and existence of specific data drive numbers (NYCO24392, NYCO24328) provided by the contractor, indicating possible discrepancies in the evidence inventory.

keyFacts: The document is an internal email chain regarding the management of digital evidence (data drives) for the case US v. Epstein.
Specific data set identifiers are discussed (NYCO24363, NYCO24392, NYCO24328, NYCO24365, NYCO24366, NYCO24371, NYCO24383) for upload to the Relativity database.
There is confusion and a request for verification about whether data drives NYCO24392 and NYCO24328 were actually provided, suggesting potential inventory or chain-of-custody issues.
The correspondence involves a contractor for the US Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USANYS), indicating post-arrest evidence handling procedures in 2020.
